posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked:
Now that the season‚Äôs concluded, I think it‚Äôs an appropriate time to ask, how beneficial really was mathematically optimizing paths using Choreo? I want to know much of an impact it really had on teams and see how much of a difference it really made.

Personally, I think Choreo was amazing and I will be encouraging my team to continue using it in future seasons. I think it helped make our paths consistent even without any vision which is a big step up from last year with just PathPlanner.

Please share your team‚Äôs insights regarding Choreo and what your team thought of it or, if you didn‚Äôt use it, why your team decided to forgo using it and whether your team will be considering switching to it for next season.

link_counts.title: Introducing Choreo: A New Approach to Swerve Trajectories

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
Hopefully this gets some traction; if not, consider asking in the actual Choreo thread for better title-recognition.

Obvious disclaimer about the reasons we initially used Choreo of course, but here goes:

6995 used Choreo for all three of our events, but due to many confounding issues with networking and drivetrain motors, our autos were not very consistent. We also never upgraded to the Sleipnir versions, due to limited time to rebuild the few paths that had trouble generating.

By the playoffs of the last event, we did have a few auto runs that worked as intended, but at that point we were often hitting opponent robots on the centerline, and that threw off odometry.

One major improvement we‚Äôd love to see is in solving times. Maybe chopping up the path between stop points before sending to the solver?

Another thing is more similar behavior to PathPlanner in regards to commands.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Dave1998:

Another thing is more similar behavior to PathPlanner in regards to commands.

This is, thankfully, not the plan.  Choreo‚Äôs command integration will (last I heard) go through the Trigger API.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked:
Let me correct myself thenüòÖ

What I meant was capability parity.

posts.name: Jordan McMichael
posts.cooked:
3538 used Choreo all season, and largely kept up with the main branch until week 6, after which we found no reason to keep up with main; all existing improvements to solve time had occurred up to that point. We look forward to future improvements to the solver coming this offseason.

We found that our autos still required on-field tuning; the carpet available to us this year was different to the competition carpet. Based on our testing prior year carpet held our paths closer to what‚Äôs drawn in Choreo than the 2024 carpet. This could be a number of effects; teams not using colsons may have seen different results.

We also found that far less tuning was required to achieve paths that met our requirements - before our first match Saturday morning we drew up our Amp-side auton that we fielded in Daly Semifinal 1-1. It didn‚Äôt hit the midline quite the way we wanted to, but I am confident that had we a second chance out it would have hit notes dead-on.

I and others have found that Choreo‚Äôs constant-torque assumption doesn‚Äôt hold very well when competing at a high level. We observed that our robot cannot quite meet the acceleration Choreo can come up with due to the drop in battery voltage, but can often make up for falling behind while braking.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
Dave1998:

One major improvement we‚Äôd love to see is in solving times. Maybe chopping up the path between stop points before sending to the solver?

The solve time increases linearly with the number of samples, so splitting up the trajectory won‚Äôt speed up the solve unless you generate them in parallel. I just opened an issue for the latter because it sounds feasible: When splitting trajectories at stop points, solve the pieces in parallel for faster solves ¬∑ Issue #458 ¬∑ SleipnirGroup/Choreo ¬∑ GitHub .

We did manage to speed up feasible solves by a lot recently by increasing the error tolerance ( TrajoptLib , Choreo ). Default was 1e-8, but drivetrains don‚Äôt need anywhere near that level of precision.

link_counts.title: When splitting trajectories at stop points, solve the pieces in parallel for faster solves ¬∑ Issue #458 ¬∑ SleipnirGroup/Choreo ¬∑ GitHub
Upgrade TrajoptLib to use larger solver tolerance (#451) ¬∑ SleipnirGroup/Choreo@13c2b43 ¬∑ GitHub

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
calcmogul:

Default was 1e-8

Without units that‚Äôs kind of meaningless, but the units depend on which constraint is most violated. As an example, if Choreo solved to meet all the constraints except 10 nanometers difference in X at a single waypoint, it would previously not be valid. Now that threshold is equivalent to 0.1 mm violation.
From my limited experience, short paths take a couple of seconds to generate, while more complicated paths, with many stop points, can take minutes to calculate, and sometimes never do.
Doesn‚Äôt that mean it has to ‚Äúgo through more options‚Äù?

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
Amicus1:

the units depend on which constraint is most violated

The solver doesn‚Äôt consider units at all. The error is determined by the infinity norm (the max absolute value of the elements) of:

The Lagrangian (how close to zero the cost gradient minus constraint gradient is, ish)

The constraint violation (how feasible it is)

The complementarity (the error in the constraint approximation introduced by the interior-point method).

The largest error contributor by unit is position, as far as I can tell, which is why 1e-4 (0.1 mm) was selected.

posts.name: Ryan Shavell
posts.cooked:
180 used Choreo the entire season, and I am extremely pleased with the results. We found that we were able to get accurate tracking of the paths fairly early in the season, and subsequently new paths often came out correct on the first or second iteration. This was a big departure from my experience with path generation tools in previous years, where tuning took considerably more time and the paths themselves needed to be repeatedly adjusted to get the preferred robot motion.

I attribute a large part of our autonomous success this season (top 3 in auto EPA , being able to write new paths that work the first try in between playoff matches) to Choreo, plan to continue heavy use of it, and look forward to new features and improvements

posts.name: Bryce Roethel
posts.cooked:
My team found great success with Choreo this season, and will continue to use it for the foreseeable future. We did make some minor changes to the Choreo application as well as ChoreoLib, of which I didn‚Äôt find time to PR in-season, however now most of these modifications have already been implemented, have better solutions planned, or are specific to my team‚Äôs needs.

Generally, we found that paths tended to ‚Äújust work‚Äù, with only minor tweaking needed for intaking notes. We originally struggled to get the robot to reliably follow paths, however that was a fault of using poor feedback gains for our swerve modules‚Äô velocity. Still, we found that we had to dial back our robot‚Äôs constraints in Choreo to be reliable, but we didn‚Äôt feel that this ultimately hindered our performance. The GUI still feels a little clunky and wasn‚Äôt entirely intuitive, but hopefully this is resolved as the project matures. Overall, we felt that Choreo greatly reduced the time needed to make new autonomous modes without sacrificing control.

Many thanks to the numerous contributors that made Choreo possible, we are excited to see what improvements are made in the upcoming offseason!

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
Dave1998:

short paths take a couple of seconds to generate, while more complicated paths, with many stop points, can take minutes to calculate, and sometimes never do.

The long generation times are caused by our poor selection of the control interval guess for complex trajectories, not the trajectory size; it‚Äôs an issue with how we formulate the minimum-time optimization problem that makes it easy to hit local infeasibility on accident. When the solver approaches a step size of zero and the problem is still infeasible, it switches to a feasibility restoration mode as a last ditch attempt. Those steps are more expensive, and feasibility restoration usually doesn‚Äôt get us to a feasible solution; it just makes the solver take longer to give up.

We‚Äôre working on improving the initial guess so the control interval counts are closer to what the optimal trajectory would have. Cubic Spline for initial guess by bruingineer ¬∑ Pull Request #148 ¬∑ SleipnirGroup/TrajoptLib ¬∑ GitHub

Dave1998:

Doesn‚Äôt that mean it has to ‚Äúgo through more options‚Äù?

Interior-point methods don‚Äôt do a combinatorial search. To give you a sense of what‚Äôs going on, consider trying to find the lowest point on a hilly landscape starting from some initial point. The interior-point method we use approximates the landscape as a bowl (first and second derivative), then takes a step to the bottom of that bowl. Then a new approximation is made and the process is repeated until it converges to a point (I‚Äôm hand-waving a lot of safeguards, but that‚Äôs the gist). Each decision variable takes a step in parallel, so there‚Äôs no combinatorial explosion.

There‚Äôs a video series linked on Sleipnir: Resources about the interior-point method that may help too.

link_counts.title: Cubic Spline for initial guess by bruingineer ¬∑ Pull Request #148 ¬∑ SleipnirGroup/TrajoptLib ¬∑ GitHub

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
bryceroethel:

The GUI still feels a little clunky and wasn‚Äôt entirely intuitive

Clunky/unintuitive in what ways?

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
jlmcmchl:

Based on our testing prior year carpet held our paths closer to what‚Äôs drawn in Choreo than the 2024 carpet. This could be a number of effects; teams not using colsons may have seen different results.

Colsons definitely behaved differently on Old vs New carpet. We struggled hard with tuning at comp until we moved to tread pattern.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
We found it completely worth it. This was our first year using these path generation tools (historically we did homebrew stuff), so we had a ton of learning experiences. We didn‚Äôt use apriltag position recovery in auto, so that was not part of our process.

We started with the WPILIB Trajectory tooling (no UI), and while it worked, no UI made it hard to manage pathing beyond 3 notes. We switched to PathPlanner, and then after getting that working, switched to Choreo around week 3 of the comp season.

Our paths include long arcs and rotations, and found PathPlanner‚Äôs generated routes when turning was involved really inconsistent. Because PP cut the path at the projected time, any turning meant we‚Äôd effectively cut the path short. This made things really inconsistent when relying on the path for actual shots and intakes. The amount of position/angle fudging to make shots was ridiculous, and ‚Äúlinked waypoints‚Äù were completely useless because we had to adjust them based on how much overshoot we required to compensate, and this carried on to any subsequent paths. For a 5 note auto, our waypoints were basically nonsensical. We tried the path auto-correction, but this basically randomized the results instead of the consistent inconsistency that we could at least deal with.

Once we switched to choreo, we almost immediately became very consistent with zero additional tuning, and waypoints were much more predictable and representative of the bot‚Äôs final position. Any number fudging is small and reasonably explained by other tuning issues and field conditions. We had by far the most successful autos in our team‚Äôs history, and choreo was key.

posts.name: kylelanman
posts.cooked:
Do you have an example of how an auto would be programmed with triggers?

This year in auto we fought some triggers we had defined in teleop and had to implement a way to disable triggers in auto.  Our take away was to use triggers less so I‚Äôm trying to understand if we are missing something or why you suggest using triggers more in auto.

posts.name: Nadav
posts.cooked:
Our team used Choreo for all of our auto routines this year, and it is the biggest reason we were able to have such high scoring autonomous routines.

Here‚Äôs my feedback on Choreo this season:

Paths required literally 0 tuning, we‚Äôve had paths run perfectly on the first try

Being able to make a 5 note auto with over 1.5 seconds to spare

PathPlanner interop, made switching over extremely easy, and allowed us to create new autos without writing any code

The split trajectories made between-path commands a breeze, for example we had the robot stop to continue intaking for 0.25 seconds if it didn‚Äôt pick up a note

Event markers, it was much easier to see them on the path instead of manually adjusting timings in a parallel group

Paths taking 45 minutes to generate only to fail

The cancel generation button taking minutes to respond

Very little control over how many samples a path as, if the interval guess is too low for one segment, all segments have to have a very high sample size

Waypoints become very difficult to manage in multi-piece autos, focus mode didn‚Äôt really help since it still showed the entire trajectory

The switch to Sleipnir in the middle of the season, that created a major hassle

Moving a waypoint 0.01 meters causing generation to fail

The .chor file having all trajectories stored in it, it makes manually re-ordering paths a huge pain, and also makes version control difficult

Ability to see graphs of acceleration, velocity, angular velocity, etc

Some way of sorting paths/constraints by name, or being able to re-order them

A measuring tool

Constraint for max acceleration and max angular velocity (useful when tracking vision targets)

Being able to see the waypoint number on a card (I noticed there‚Äôs already a PR for it)

Overall, our team has had an incredible experience with Choreo, and I‚Äôm looking forward to seeing its success in the future!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
kylelanman:

This year in auto we fought some triggers we had defined in teleop and had to implement a way to disable triggers in auto.

You can avoid this by creating the teleop-mode-only triggers on TeleopInit .

kylelanman:

Our take away was to use triggers less so I‚Äôm trying to understand if we are missing something or why you suggest using triggers more in auto.

You should use Triggers whenever command groups are proving to be too rigid of a tool for the problem you‚Äôre solving.  This is typically the case for complicated whole-robot autonomous routines.

Command composition is powerful but it is not the only tool in the library for representing composite behaviors.
